title: Mach-Zehnder Interferometer
description: Demonstrates quantum superposition and interference by splitting coherent light into two paths and recombining them to create interference fringes.
physics_explanation: Coherent laser light is split into two paths by the input beam splitter, creating quantum superposition |ψ⟩ = (|upper⟩ + |lower⟩)/√2. The phase shifter introduces controllable phase difference φ between paths. At the output beam splitter, the paths recombine and interfere, producing intensity oscillations I ∝ 1 + cos(φ) that demonstrate wave-particle duality and quantum interference.

component_justifications.Coherent Laser: HeNe laser at 632.8nm provides stable, coherent light source necessary for high-visibility interference - coherence length must exceed path difference
component_justifications.Input BS: 50:50 beam splitter creates equal amplitude superposition of photon being in upper and lower arms simultaneously
component_justifications.Upper Mirror: Redirects upper arm beam back toward output beam splitter while maintaining beam alignment and optical path
component_justifications.Lower Mirror: Redirects lower arm beam back toward output beam splitter, completing the interferometer geometry
component_justifications.Phase Control: Adjustable phase shifter (piezo mirror or glass plate) enables scanning of relative phase between arms to observe interference fringes
component_justifications.Output BS: Second 50:50 beam splitter recombines the two arms, enabling quantum interference between the superposed paths
component_justifications.Detector 1: Photodiode measures transmitted output intensity, showing constructive/destructive interference as phase is varied
component_justifications.Detector 2: Second photodiode at reflected output port demonstrates complementary interference pattern - when Det1 is bright, Det2 is dark

expected_outcome: Sinusoidal interference fringes as phase is scanned, with 100% visibility for perfect coherence. Detectors show complementary oscillations: when one detector sees maximum intensity, the other sees minimum, demonstrating energy conservation and quantum interference.
